Introduction

Ewing sarcoma is an aggressive, bony malignancy most often diagnosed in adolescents.  It typically affects the long bone diaphyses (

figure 1
), pelvis, or axial skeleton.  X-ray classically demonstrates a central permeative ("moth-eaten") lesion with a layered ("onion skin") periosteal reaction.

Epidemiology



Ewing sarcoma is the second-most common primary bone malignancy in children (after osteosarcoma), with a peak incidence between ages 10-15.  It is rare among adults.

Pathogenesis



Ewing sarcoma is a primitive tumor of unclear origin (likely arising from neuroectodermal or mesenchymal stem cells).  Most cases are driven by a translocation involving EWSR1 on chromosome 22 and FLI1 on chromosome 11 (ie, a t(11;22) translocation).  This results in a fusion protein that functions as an abnormal transcription factor and leads to uncontrolled cell proliferation.

Clinical presentation



Patients with Ewing sarcoma are most commonly adolescents who have chronic, localized pain that is often worse at night and does not respond to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.  Physical activity may be limited, particularly if a pathologic fracture is present.  The most commonly affected sites are the long bone diaphyses (eg, femur, tibia, humerus), pelvis, and axial skeleton.  Local erythema, warmth, and swelling are common, and a tender soft tissue mass may be present on examination.



Systemic findings (eg, fever, weight loss) often indicate metastatic disease.  Asymmetric breath sounds or rales may suggest spread to the lungs, the most common site for metastasis.  Additional findings, such as petechiae and peripheral neuropathy, suggest the presence of bone marrow metastasis and central nervous system metastasis, respectively.

Evaluation



The initial step in evaluation is imaging, typically x-ray first, then MRI:



  • X-ray (
    image 1
    ) shows the following:

    • Poorly defined, permeative ("moth-eaten") lytic lesion seen as multiple or coalesced lucencies within a long bone diaphysis, pelvis, or axial skeleton.
    • Aggressive, lamellated periosteal reaction consisting of concentric layers of new bone ("onion skinning").  Other nonspecific, aggressive periosteal reactions suggestive of rapid tumor growth (eg, Codman triangle) can occur.
  • MRI is performed after x-ray to evaluate tumor extension into the bone, growth plate, and/or soft tissue (eg, nerves, blood vessels).  MRI is also performed for surgical planning because it can identify necrotic or hypervascular areas that should be avoided during surgery.


Laboratory evaluation shows the following:



  • Inflammatory markers (eg, ESR, CRP) are often elevated, especially in patients with systemic symptoms.
  • Lactate dehydrogenase may be elevated, reflecting overall tumor burden.

Diagnosis and pathology



Biopsy is the gold standard for definitive diagnosis, and histopathology shows sheets of uniform, small, round, blue cells with scant cytoplasm separated by fibrous septa and patches of necrosis (

image 2
).  Cytogenetic analysis of biopsy specimens typically reveals a t(11;22) translocation.

Differential diagnosis



  • Osteosarcoma (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
    ):  the most common primary bone malignancy in adolescents.  It presents with chronic, localized pain and a soft tissue mass.  It is often found in the metaphysis of long bones (eg, femur, tibia).  X-ray typically reveals an ill-defined lesion (
    image 3
    ) with osteoblastic (radiodense) and osteolytic (radiolucent) areas and an aggressive periosteal reaction (eg, "sunburst" pattern, Codman triangle).  Histopathology shows pleomorphic malignant cells that produce new osteoid tissue.
  • Osteoclastoma (giant cell tumor of bone) (
    image 4
    ):  a benign but locally aggressive lesion located in the epiphyses of long bones.  It presents in adulthood with pain and swelling, and x-ray demonstrates an expansile lytic area with a "soap bubble" appearance due to bony trabeculae within the lesion.
  • Multiple myeloma (
    image 5
    ):  a plasma cell malignancy that is extremely rare in patients age <40.  Imaging often reveals multiple lytic lesions, osteopenia, and pathologic fractures.
  • Unicameral bone cysts (
    image 6
    ):  a benign lesion that typically occurs at the proximal femur or humerus of children and young adults.  It is usually asymptomatic (unless a pathologic fracture is present) and seen incidentally on x-ray as a lytic lesion with well-defined margins.
  • Osteoid osteoma (
    image 7
    ):  a benign bone tumor most commonly located in the femur, presenting with nocturnal pain that classically responds to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.  X-ray demonstrates benign features such as a well-defined lytic lesion and a solid periosteal reaction.
  • Osteomyelitis (
    image 8
    ):  a bacterial bone infection that causes progressive pain, limited mobility, and signs of systemic inflammation (eg, fever, leukocytosis).  X-ray often reveals an ill-defined lytic lesion with a periosteal reaction.  Histopathology of chronic osteomyelitis demonstrates inflammatory cells, necrotic bone, and irregular bony trabeculae.

Management



A bone scintigraphy, CT scan, or positron emission tomography scan is performed to assess for metastatic disease.  Staging is categorized as either:



  • Localized:  primary bone with or without surrounding tissue
  • Metastatic:  lymph node or systemic (most commonly in the lungs or other bones)


Systemic chemotherapy is the cornerstone of treatment.  Additional therapies include local radiation or surgical resection.

Prognosis



The survival rate for localized disease is favorable with multimodal therapy.  Poor prognostic factors include metastases at diagnosis (most commonly lung and bone/bone marrow), primary nonâ€“long bone tumor (eg, axial skeleton), and age >18.

Summary



Ewing sarcoma (

) is the second-most common primary bone malignancy in children (after osteosarcoma).  It typically affects the long bone diaphyses or pelvis and presents with localized, chronic pain and swelling.  X-ray classically demonstrates a central permeative ("moth-eaten") lesion with a layered ("onion skin") periosteal reaction.  Biopsy is diagnostic and shows sheets of uniform, small, round, blue cells.
